awd_titl_txt: ADVANCE Partnership: Council of Public Liberal Arts Colleges Partnering and Liaising Across the Nation
awd_abstract_narration:
SUNY Geneseo will lead an NSF ADVANCE Partnership project called the COPLAC Partnering and Liaising Across the Nation (PLAN) Initiative to provide transformational institutional change strategies for COPLAC institutions.  The COPLAC (Council of Public Liberal Arts Colleges) consortium includes twenty-nine, state-funded, predominantly undergraduate institutions (PUIs) across the nation.  All members of COPLAC share a mission to provide a high-quality, affordable education to their constituents.  The project will undertake two main efforts: 1) training and empowering influencers such as administrators and chairs to problem solve and create equity goals, and 2) creating facilitated virtual professional affinity groups among COPLAC faculty. The training will be integrated in the COPLAC annual meeting to support the participation of institutional leadership. The affinity groups will be tailored to support the unique needs of faculty at PUIs and create a conduit for sharing faculty equity issues with COPLAC leaders.

The project will ensure that efforts include attention to intersectional issues in STEM academic workplaces which will contribute to the effectiveness of the ADVANCE strategies that are being adapted.  The project includes a strong plan for sharing and disseminating information on the project which will be broadly applicable to many other PUIs.  In addition, COPLAC institutions that are part of state systems of higher education offer an additional avenue for sharing strategies developed with this project with the state-wide systems.  This project has the potential to reduce inequities within the COPLAC consortium institutions and may result in a useful model for other PUIs facing similar challenges across the nation. 

The NSF ADVANCE program is designed to foster gender equity through a focus on the identification and elimination of organizational barriers that impede the full participation and advancement of diverse faculty in academic institutions.  Organizational barriers that inhibit equity may exist in policies, processes, practices, and the organizational culture and climate.  ADVANCE "Partnership" awards provide support to collaborations among STEM professional societies and academic and non-academic non-profit organizations designed to broaden the implementation of evidence-based equity strategies and have a national or regional reach.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The University of Virginia's College at Wise collaborated in an NSF ADVANCE Partnership with SUNY Geneseo (lead institution) and the University of North Carolina at Asheville in a project titled, COPLAC Partnering and Liaising Across the Nation (PLAN) Initiative. The COPLAC (Council of Public Liberal Arts Colleges) consortium includes twenty-nine, state-funded, predominantly undergraduate institutions (PUIs) across the nation.

Project Outcomes: The COPLAC ADVANCE Partnership provided professional support and networking to women STEM faculty and worked towards institutional change through administrator professional development at the Chair and Provost levels.

To promote equity for women STEM faculty across COPLAC, the project supported Affinity Groups starting in 2020.  In the 2022-23 academic year, the COPLAC Partnership served 101 participants in 18 Affinity Groups. The intersectional themes include Women of Color, LGBTQ+, Motherhood, and Work-Life Balance. From the project's external evaluation, participants reported positive impacts from participating in the Affinity Groups, including receiving needed support, resources, and guidance on navigating academic careers.

In 2022 the project co-sponsored the COPLAC Summer Institute on Liberal Learning for Women Faculty in STEM. The topics covered included becoming an effective advocate and ally for women and marginalized faculty, work-life balance/work-life Integration, invisible labor, and tenure and promotion. Participants reported feeling empowered to be advocates for themselves and others and having improved motivation to set career goals while being more aware of the downsides of invisible labor. They left wanting to be a better ally and promote gender equity at their home institutions. In all, there were 30 participants, many of which were Affinity Group members. An Institute Statement was prepared and 86% of participants rated the Summer Institute as Outstanding.

To understand the priority areas for promoting faculty equity at PUIs, administrators and faculty were surveyed to study the prevalence of equity-promoting policies and practices across the consortium as well as the perceptions of the impact or effectiveness of these policies and practices. Results showed variation in the existence of equity-related policies and practices across the COPLAC institutions as well as significant levels of disagreement between administration and faculty on the extent to which policies and practices were having a positive impact. The areas with the greatest discrepancies include a process to rectify differences in research support, including funding, space/equipment or other resources, across faculty and a process to monitor differences in service load across faculty. These findings informed the professional development and reports provided to COPLAC Chairs, Provosts, and Presidents.

In 2022 and 2023, the COPLAC ADVANCE Partnership provided the Faculty Equity Training for Department Chairs (virtually). The goals were to provide resources and professional development workshops in faculty equity issues and to facilitate collaboration across institutions. The topics included workload allocation and reward, peer and student evaluation bias mitigation, and resource allocation. It provided an opportunity to: discuss and reflect on personal experiences; share data and resources with faculty colleagues; and strategize over next steps. Participants found it useful to discuss experiences with colleagues at other institutions and were reaffirmed in the changes they already wanted to implement. The vast majority of respondents (90%) said that they would recommend this training to other Department Chairs in STEM Disciplines at COPLAC institutions. Additional interactions with administrative leadership across COPLAC also came from presentations and discussions at the 2022 and 2023 COPLAC Beard Leadership Circle. The opportunities to engage with COPLAC Presidents and Provosts were at the AAC&U Annual Meetings and COPLAC Annual Meetings. At the 2023 COPLAC Annual Meeting, a workshop was provided on reforms for a more equitable tenure and promotion process.

While manuscripts are still in preparation and review with project findings and outcomes, the ADVANCE Partnership has disseminated at several conferences and audiences. The Partnership has presented at the Midwest Political Science Association, the Equity in STEM Community Convening, the UC Santa Cruz Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion Seminar Series, the Faculty Women of Color in the Academy, the American Chemical Society National Meeting, the American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, and the AAC&U Transforming STEM Higher Education Conference.
